posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked: gradle build times, especially on students’ laptops. Also building C++ with gradle.
Hungarian notation, especially since all the WPILib examples use it without explaining why.  This means it could easily end up in lots of teams’ code where no one has any real idea why it’s there.

posts.name: Stephen Ostermiller
posts.cooked:
When people post to these forums asking for help with their code and all you have to work with is a screenshot of their code.  If I want to help them and correct their code, I need to type it all out again.  Some important bits will probably be cut off.

Those asking for help are likely students with little experience, so I try to cut them some slack. But there are two really good ways to share code:

Use markdown formatting with code blocks using three backticks at the start and end. Specifying the language after the first three backticks: ```java
int x = 3;
int y = 4;
```

Share a link to the file you are working on in your branch in your github repository.

link_counts.title: FRC pet peeves: what really grinds your gears?

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
Open command pallete WPILIB Simulate Robot Code Wait for a rebuild/check “Sim Gui or Real Driverstation” then it launches the sim.

Every single time I run this I get distracted by something else during that few seconds (or minutes on some student laptops), click away from prompt and have to start over. If it’d just ask before doing the rest of the process it’d be fine.

The change in WPILib (This Year) that then required Spark Maxes (Unsure if that is the plural for Spark Max) to require an additional object, being a SparkMaxConfig, to invert motors, instead of just saying m_insertMotorHere.setInverted(); as I don’t think FIRST wants us using deprecated code.

Edit: Realized that it was due to RevLib and not WPILib

posts.name: 829 The Digital Goats Official Curmudgeon.
posts.cooked: Programmers

posts.name: Elijah Beard
posts.cooked: I think you have a bone to pick with Rev Robotics, not WPILib. Revlib is the library used to control Spark Maxes (I am going along with this pluralization),  which is separate from WPILib.
Feedback and feedforward constants without units, espeically if they are not in base SI units and radians.

posts.name: Jason Daming
posts.cooked:
Do you often find yourself choosing each of them?  A little known option is to bypass this check by changing “Skip Select Simulate Extension” in the vscode optoins for WPILib.

For example I almost never do DS sim so just have it always auto go to the simGUI but some people have it auto skip simGUI etc.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: My hero. <3 Works like a charm. I’m on Linux, so I can’t run the real Driverstation anyway.

posts.name: Stephen Ostermiller
posts.cooked:
tekdemo:

I’m on Linux, so I can’t run the real Driverstation anyway

That is another pet peeve.  Why is there so much Windows-only FRC stuff?  And a lot of non-open-source as well.

Another recently discovered pet peeve I have: Trying to figure out commands and subsystems in C++, I have no clue why there is a file called Command.h and a file called Command.cpp for one command, I’m very much used to Java and therefore one file per command (or subsystem)

posts.name: Stephen Ostermiller
posts.cooked:

It can still be your pet peeve, but there are technical reasons based on how C++ is defined and implemented.
